(Throughout the questionnaire, "Saskatchewan" means the area which is now Saskatchewan)

PLEASE NOTE

This questionnaire is intended for persons who came to Saskatchewan before 1914, and most of the questions are about that early period, although in a few questions information for later years is asked for.

If you cannot answer a question, leave the space blank. We realize that any one person will not be able to answer all questions, so answer those that apply to your experience and that you can remember, and leave the others.

Use extra sheets of paper if there is not enough space on the questionnaire.

Your co-operation in answering this questionnaire will be very much appreciated, and all questionnaires are preserved in the Saskatchewan Archives as part of the permanent record of our province.

SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRES.

No. 4

Pioneer Churches.

1. To what religious services did you go when you first settled in your district?

   Anglican services (not sure) no services

   Where did your neighbors go to church?

   Anglican no services

   How long was it after the first settlers came to your area before services of church worship were organized?

   Anglican - 1874 - Henry Mission

2. By whom were religious services held in your community before a regular church became established (by a clergyman from some other place, etc.)? Give details of the arrangement, telling where services were held, and give dates if possible.

   Mr. John Hines took religious services before the mission church.

   How was the clergyman supported?

   Anglican Church (England)

3. Was the school house used for church services? Give dates.

   Used school while facing church.

   Was it used by congregations of more than one denomination on alternate Sundays?

   No

   Did the same congregation ever support both types of services and give equal financial support?

   -

   Where did the clergyman (or clergymen) live, and how far was it from the school house?

   Mission

   Right there (school & church both part of mission)

   How did he get to the school house to conduct services?

   -

   Was he entertained in homes or supplied with accommodation for the night?

   Entertained not for night

   Were services continued throughout the winter months, as well as other seasons of the year?

   Yes

   Who put on the fire for school house services in winter?

   hired help

   What other charges, or appointments, did the clergyman have besides the one at your school house?

   White Rock Lake

   Describe the financial arrangements.

   all from England

4. Were homes or other buildings such as stores used for church services in your community? Describe the arrangements.

   House services out of Henry Mission in most Mike district before 1919
5. If you had a church building, give the date it was built.

Who designed the building? Both built by George Young - second one helped by son Harold Young.

Who built it? Both built by George Young - second one helped by son Harold Young.

What material was it made of? Lumber.

How many people did it seat?

What was the name and denomination of the church?

St. Luke's Anglican.

6. Describe the steps taken in arranging for the building of the church, telling who started it, how money was secured, etc.

St. Luke's - Mr. John M. Cameron - canvassed the settlers - paid carpenters some voluntary labour.

How many families were in the congregation?

7. Describe any make-shifts or savings resorted to in the building of the church, and in securing furniture and supplies for it.

W.A. supplied furniture.

8. Is this first building still in use? Yes.

If not, tell why it is not used now, and what happened to it.

The first St. Mark's a log building wasn't durable.

9. When did you have a resident clergyman? All the time.

Where did he come from?

What provision was made for living quarters for him - a residence built, etc.?

Residence was supplied by Anglican Church.

10. Did any other denomination use this church building for services? No

Describe the arrangement.

11. Tell what other churches were built in your community, either before your church was built, or any time since. Give dates if possible, denomination of church, and any changes which have occurred in the use of the building, that is, if some denomination other than the one who built it is now using the church, or if it is used for some other purpose.

Are all these churches in town? If not, give distances from town, and from one another.

If not built in town, why were they not built there?
12. Was your church established as a home mission? Yes

Describe the arrangements as to finance, student ministers, etc.

Collection until W.A. started paying part of salary.

13. If families did not have a church of their own denomination in the community, did they usually go to some other church, or not attend at all? Explain.

Only once in a while, other denomination came.

Did they have any special religious service of some kind in the home if they could not go to church, or if there was no public religious service?

If families had been attending and supporting a church other than their own denomination, or had not attended because their own church was not present, how well did they support their own church if it became established in their community at a later date?

14. How often and at what time were services held in the church, school or other building?

Every two weeks!

15. Did laymen conduct church services when a clergyman was not available? Describe the circumstances.

Teachers from the mission when ministers away.

16. Did you have an organ for the service? Who played it? When was it bought? How was the money raised for it?

When? W.A. raised money.

17. Did you have a choir? No How many were in it? When?

Who started it?

Were any of the persons who led the choir or sang in it trained musicians? Explain.

Violin and male duet under Mr. Macdonald (Henry mission minister)

18. Was any other kind of music or musical instrument used in the services? Describe.

Violin & male duet under Mr. Macdonald (Henry mission minister)

19. What kind of religious instruction for the young, such as Sunday School or Catechism classes, were held? Give dates when they were started.

Confirmation Classes after services.

How often were they held?

Events with four or five months.

How many children attended?

A dozen - 8 - 4815

Who was in charge of these and helped with the teaching?

Minister

20. What organization (or organizations) was formed to help with the support of the church? W.A.

What year was it started? 1919 How often did it meet? Every three weeks

How many women or men belonged to it? Approx. 8.
21. In what year was the first church picnic held? Where? 
Describe the church picnics of early days, telling how many attended, what you had to eat and drink, what amusements there were, changes which occurred in later years, and any other details about them which you remember. (There are questions on the Pioneer Recreation Questionnaire dealing with picnics, so if you wish to give the information there, you need not repeat it here.)

Sold lunches for the church. Races for everybody.

22. In what year was the first fowl supper or bazaar held? Where? 
Was it held every year after that? 
What differences do you notice between the dishes served at the suppers in the early days, and those served now?

No suppers now.

What differences are there in serving methods (help yourself, plates served already filled, etc.)?

What changes are there in the price of suppers?

Describe any changes which you have noticed in the needlework offered for sale, in type of work or articles brought, those that were most popular at various times, changes in price, or any other details which you may remember.

Quilts, shirts (boys), stockings, mitts (knitted), meccassins (9, 25)

Plaques, embroidered pillow slips, aprons, children's dresses

Was a concert of some kind held in connection with the suppers or bazaars in the first years? Describe.

Dances afterwards. Big crowds at school house. Singing by different men & women.

23. Describe any other activities that were carried on to assist in raising money for the church.

Canvassing in early years.

24. Name any other organizations or meetings associated with the church, telling when they were started, how often they met, and their purpose and activities.

Girls' Auxiliary started in 1945

25. When was any plan of systematic giving for the support of the church and clergyman adopted?

Of what nature, - weekly envelopes, etc.?
26. What interest or activity was there in the support of home missions? — very little foreign missions?

27. How far did some of the people have to travel to church service? — farther 4 miles.

What means of travel was used?
— team or walked —

28. What nationalities were represented in the congregation, and in approximately what proportion?
— Dutch - English - Part Indian —

29. Were there special revival or mission services in the early days? Describe.
— at Sandy Lake, early days —

30. What arrangements were there to provide for the training of the clergy?
— the ministry picked out promising boys and sent to college —

31. What differences did you notice in church life on the prairies as compared with the community you came from?

32. To what extent did the social life of the community centre around the church service (held in the church, school or other building) in the early days?
— In early days a lot of social life was around the church —

33. Is the church as important a place now of people gathering together for companionship and sociability as it was in the early years? Explain.
— fewer people attend church —

34. Is the first membership roll of your church still in the community?
If you can, give the name of the person who has it.
— could be at Sandy Lake. You could ask Rev. Stanley Guthrie —

Do you have any pictures or photographs of your earliest church or of homes where the first services were held, or do you know of anyone who has such pictures?

35. Describe any special features or unusual incidents of pioneer churches, or anything connected with it which you found interesting, not already mentioned. (Use other sheets, or back of this sheet if necessary.)
Pioneer Address: WHITEWOOD, SASK.

Year you came to Saskatchewan: Sept. 3, 1882

No. 4

Pioneer Churches.

1. To what religious services did you go when you first settled in your district? None there was no house at 1862.

Where did your neighbors go to church? The first Methodist Church was built July 1885. It was enlarged 14 ft x 10 and cost $800. In 1885 it was enlarged.

How long was it after the first settlers came to your area before services of church worship were organized? On July 11-1883 the first Anglican Service was held.

2. How many religious services were held in your community before a regular church became established (by a clergyman from some other place, etc.)? Give details of the arrangement, telling where services were held, and give dates if possible. In 1885 a residence was built for the minister. It was used for the first annual garden party.

How was the clergyman supported? Sunday School was under Charles Bachelor and Mrs. J. H. Knowler.

3. Was the school house used for church services? Give dates. No.

Was it used by congregations of more than one denomination on alternate Sundays? The Presbyterian Minister Rev. Alex Hamilton used it.

Did the same congregation ever support both types of services and give equal financial support? The School Sunday at 3 o'clock every other Sunday.

Where did the clergyman (or clergymen) live, and how far was it from the school house? In Whitewood 6 miles.

How did he get to the school house to conduct services? Horses.

Was he entertained in homes or supplied with accommodation for the night? Yes.

Were services continued throughout the winter months, as well as other seasons of the year? Weather permitting.

Who put on the fire for school house services in winter? Who was first there.

What other charges, or appointments, did the clergyman have besides the one at your school house? Burrows School and St. John's School.

Describe the financial arrangements. I don't know.

4. Were homes or other buildings such as stores used for church services in your community? Describe the arrangements.
5. If you had a church building, give the date it was built.

Who designed the building? The Precinct Anglican Church

Who built it? It was built in 1902 July 3 opened

What material was it made of? Stone

How many people did it seat? 750

What was the name and denomination of the church? St Mary's Anglican

6. Describe the steps taken in arranging for the building of the church, telling who started it, how money was secured, etc.

How many families were in the congregation? Maybe 30

7. Describe any make-shifts or savings resorted to in the building of the church, and in securing furniture and supplies for it.

8. Is this first building still in use? No

If not, tell why it is not used now, and what happened to it. Gone down

9. When did you have a resident clergyman? 1888 England

What provision was made for living quarters for him - a residence built, etc.? Yes

10. Did any other denomination use this church building for services? No

Describe the arrangement.

11. Tell what other churches were built in your community, either before your church was built, or any time since. Give dates if possible, denomination of church, and any changes which have occurred in the use of the building, that is, if some denomination other than the one who built it is now using the church, or if it is used for some other purpose.

Methodist church Now used as Masonic Hall

Presbyterian church Still in use

United church Still in use

Roman Catholic Church Still in use

Are all these churches in town? Yes

If not, give distances from town, and from one another.

St Mary's Anglican Church

If not built in town, why were they not built there?
12. Was your church established as a home mission?
   Describe the arrangements as to finance, student ministers, etc.

13. If families did not have a church of their own denomination in the community, did they usually go to some other church, or not attend at all? Explain. Yes

Did they have any special religious service of some kind in the home if they could not go to church, or if there was no public religious service? Yes

If families had been attending and supporting a church other than their own denomination, or had not attended because their own church was not present, how well did they support their own church if it became established in their community at a later date?

14. How often and at what time were services held in the church, school or other building? Twice on Sunday
    Sunday School every Sunday

15. Did laymen conduct church services when a clergyman was not available? Describe the circumstances. Yes, they have

16. Did you have an organ for the service? Yes Who played it? Mrs. F.J. Pearson
    When was it bought? How was the money raised for it?

17. Did you have a choir? No How many were in it? Not in early days
    Who started it? When?
    Were any of the persons who led the choir or sang in it trained musicians? No

18. Was any other kind of music or musical instrument used in the services? Describe. No

19. What kind of religious instruction for the young, such as Sunday School or Catechism classes, were held? Give dates when they were started. 1889
    How often were they held? Every Sunday at 2:30
    How many children attended? Maybe 25 adults, 2 children
    Who was in charge of these and helped with the teaching? Wesley Gillis

20. What organization (or organizations) was formed to help with the support of the church? Ladies W.A.
    What year was it started? 1900 How often did it meet?
    How many women or men belonged to it? 16
21. In what year was the first church picnic held? 1910 Where? 3 miles North of Whitewood in a Ravine

Describe the church picnics of early days, telling how many attended, what you had to eat and drink, what amusements there were, changes which occurred in later years, and any other details about them which you remember. (There are questions on the Pioneer Recreation Questionnaire dealing with picnics, so if you wish to give the information there, you need not repeat it here.)

22. In what year was the first fowl supper or bazaar held? 1910 Where? Parish Hall

Was it held every year after that? Yes

What differences do you notice between the dishes served at the suppers in the early days, and those served now? Not much there was always lots of good food

What differences are there in serving methods (help yourself, plates served already filled, etc.)? Help yourself

What changes are there in the price of suppers? 25¢ to 100¢ to 125¢

Describe any changes which you have noticed in the needlework offered for sale, in type of work or articles brought, those that were most popular at various times, changes in price, or any other details which you may remember.

Was a concert of some kind held in connection with the suppers or bazaars in the first years? Dance Describe.

23. Describe any other activities that were carried on to assist in raising money for the church.

24. Name any other organizations or meetings associated with the church, telling when they were started, how often they met, and their purpose and activities.

Every Member Canvas

25. When was any plan of systematic giving for the support of the church and clergyman adopted? 1889

Of what nature, - weekly envelopes, etc.? Envelopes
26. What interest or activity was there in the support of home missions?
   foreign missions?

27. How far did some of the people have to travel to church service?
   What means of travel was used? walked or open car

28. What nationalities were represented in the congregation, and in approximately what proportion?
   Nova Scotia & English

29. Were there special revival or mission services in the early days? Describe. No

30. What arrangements were there to provide for the training of the clergy? None

31. What differences did you notice in church life on the prairies as compared with the community you came from?
   I was only 12 years old and did not take much notice

32. To what extent did the social life of the community centre around the church service (held in the church, school or other building) in the early days?
   only on Sunday

33. Is the church as important a place now of people gathering together for companionship and sociability as it was in the early years? Yes
   Explain.

34. Is the first membership roll of your church still in the community? No
   If you can, give the name of the person who has it.
   Do you have any pictures or photographs of your earliest church or of homes where the first services were held, or do you know of anyone who has such pictures?

35. Describe any special features or unusual incidents of pioneer churches, or anything connected with it which you found interesting, not already mentioned.
   (Use other sheets, or back of this sheet if necessary.)
   My wife Father used to have services in his house and he led the singing on an accordion and it did very well. We had pictures of a lot of old time happenings but the house got burned and destroyed everything.

At Wauwota, the summer I was there, there was no organ in the school for use in the church services. Once we were invited for "Choir Practice" a few miles through the brush part way to the Drinnan home where there was an organ. We had a good time going over a number of young people in a democratic manner. The student minister for the summer always said "he couldnt sing." This night when he was asked, for we thought he could. He consented and in a drone said over & over "The Old Man's Bore." We begged him to stop but he kept on till he told us that he wasn't bothered again that way. He was a fine speaker though, in church & well liked. On the way back on the prairie road, a bad electrical storm came up. It was dark only when a flash of lightning showed if we were on the road. The driver of the team would stop once in awhile, afraid we might be too near the Pipestone banks. We were lost, but at last, in one of the flashes, the light of a burning lime kiln was seen. Pioneer Churches.

1. To what religious services did you go when you first settled in your district? Services conducted by Lay Preachers who belonged to the Congregational and Methodist Churches. John Teece, William Dixon and Samuel Chipperfield. These services were held in homes and then in School house.

How long was it after the first settlers came to your area before services of church worship were organized? About ten years.

as above.

How was the clergyman supported?
No charge

3. Was the school house used for church services? Give dates.
Yes, after it was built which was built in 1897.

Was it used by congregations of more than one denomination on alternate Sundays? Later on a Presbyterian Minister came from other points and conducted Services on Sunday afternoon. He came from the Kenlis charge.

Did the same congregation ever support both types of services and give equal financial support? Yes.

Drove with team and buggy.

Yes, if necessary.

If the weather wasn't too severe.

Some of the nearby members such as Mr. John Coulthard who lived close to the school.

What other charges, or appointments, did the clergyman have besides the one at your school house?
Kenlis and Wright's appointments.

Describe the financial arrangements.
Salaries were very low in those days and the Minister received what support the congregation could give and the balance was made up if possible by mission funds.

Motherwell, it was a very fine building I am not sure who designed the building. Who built it?

What material was it made of? brick How many people did it seat? about 250.

What was the name and denomination of the church? the Presbyterian. First Minister Reverend Alex Robson, Second Rev. Wm. Bell. In 1910 a frame Church was built at Hubbard, the seating capacity of about 75.

or village? Are all these churches in town? Yes. If not, give distances from town, and from one another.

At Hubbard Miss McFee, the school teachers who were available and S. Chipperfield was Superintendent.

Church picnics were held at Pheasant Forks starting in 1883 and was held in July of that year and were continued on July 4th of each year for many years. We say Pheasant Forks was situated about ten miles from Chickney and the Methodist Colony was established in 1862 with a Minister and several Lay Preachers. Our people from Chickney used to attend some of these picnics when the writer became old enough to drive the horse and buggy.

As far as I can remember about 1905.

Yes, we think so.

In the early days they were usually useful garments for babies and children with a number of aprons and other lines made for women. Now a days a lot more fancy articles are made as the women have more time than they had in the early days.

Of what nature, - weekly envelopes, etc.?

The budget funds took in both the foreign and home missions.

about six to seven miles.

Horse and buggy or team and democrat as a rule. In the very early years they use to use lumber wagons sometimes with oxen.

Occasionally they use to have them.

No special arrangements.

My Father and Mother would notice quite a difference, my maternal Grandfather was a Congregational Minister in England. I was too young when I left England to remember.

It was one of the most regular forms of get together that the people in the early days had. After the services was over a lot of those attending would visit with their neighbors for about an hour or more and in quite a number of cases go over to some nearby neighbor for their evening meal. The meeting we may say was usually held in the afternoon.

33. Is the church as important a place now of people gathering together for companionship and sociability as it was in the early years?
Possibly in one way it is for Christian fellowship but of course the time spent after service is only a matter of few minutes friends exchanging greetings and then passing on to go home.

No we do not think so.
If you can, give the name of the person who has it.

No I do not think so.

(Use other sheets, or back of this sheet if necessary.)
In the early days in addition to the regular services in the homes or school house about once each summer a camp meeting would be held, this would be in a nice bluff setting and people would attend with wagons and buggies and of course some walking and about four or five local preachers would take part in the service. A wagon would be drawn up and the speakers would use the wagon as a platform to make the speech. The services use to start about half past ten and continue until about four to five o'clock. Quite a number of people brought their lunches with them.

1. To what religious services did you go when you first settled in your district? The Presbyterian church service was held in my father's home. In the summer of 1885 a student by the name of McLeod held services. This was the beginning of the church in our district. McLeod was afterwards Principal of an Indian school in Regina. I believe he stayed there until he died some years later.

Where did your neighbors go to church?

Anyone who cared to go to church came to our home regardless of religious connections. At first, until we got our story and a half house built, McLeod held service in our little, one-room log hut which would hold about 15 people if there were more came.

How long did you attend your church?

The first homesteaders came in May 1882 but most of them went back to Ont. for the winter and brought their families out in 1883.

2. By whom were religious services held in your community before a regular church became established (by a clergyman from some other place, etc.)?

Give details of the arrangement, telling where services were held, and give dates if possible. Mr. McLeod boarded at Carlyle, don't know where, and walked 15 miles Saturday to our home. He stayed all night, had service on Sunday morning and father drove him halfway back to Carlyle after service Sunday. An ordained Methodist minister was stationed at Carlyle too and sometimes walked approximately five miles east.

Some of the congregation worshipped at the HOME MISSION BOARD, Toronto. This no doubt would apply to the Methodist minister, Wilson by name, as well as Mr. McLeod. Wilson was married and had a family and home at Carlyle.

3. Was the school house used for church services? Give dates.

The Clare Presbyterian Log church was built in 1883. The school was not built until the fall of 1886 and not opened until the spring of 1887. It was the first teacher in the Clare School.

Was there any congregation of more than one denomination on alternate Sundays? Yes, later on the Methodists used it; these were the two and only religious bodies at work in the settlement.

Did the same congregation ever support both types of services and give equal financial support? No I should think not as there were enough of these two congregations to keep a church student in the summer if not the year around.

Where did the clergyman (or clergymen) live, and how far was it from the school house? The Presbyterian student boarded in a home or, there was a hotel in Carlyle. After the log church was built they boarded with Mr. John Hines' home on whose farm the church stood.

How did he get to the school house to conduct services? Many of the students walked as much as twenty miles on Sunday leaving Saturday morning or after Sunday service for as many as three Sunday services in the day. They might get a drive at times.

Were the students in homes or supplied with accommodation for the night?

The best was always given to the minister. They were usually loved and great reverence was accorded them. The pioneers were a hospital people and no one was ever permitted to leave without a meal or bed if needed, be they missionary of Jewish packmen.

Were services continued throughout the winter months, as well as other seasons of the year? Yes when ordained men were in the field. Students had to report back for study in September or October at Winnipeg or Toronto.

Who put on the fire for school house services in winter? Sometimes the winter church service was held in a home because it was warmer and more a room for horses other than the farmer living nearest the church would put the fire on.

What other charges, or appointments, etc., is a sweeping question to answer. Our two ministers were the Rev. Wm. MacKillop who had a full swing all the way to A FILE O' BONES 113 miles as the crow flies West. There was a Presbyterian man, Wm. Patterson, east and south Alameda-Orchard direction in 1882-3 and another at Mossemin north 75 miles away.

Describe the financial arrangements. I am not in a position to do this but the most of their salary came from the Home Mission Board at Toronto. I can't remember what salary they got tho I would likely know at the time. The homesteaders gave willingly what money they could but they were still striving for a living themselves and money scarce.

Mr. Skae retired from the ministry and now farms near Kennedy, Sask. This church was also logs from Moose Mountain taken out and built by the young men of the congregation. This was used by both Methodists and Presbyterians until the brick Methodists built their frame church in the town of Arcola in '02.

The first picnic held in this settlement was at Picnic Hill, Moose Mountain July 1st 1891.

People came in wagons, on horseback or in buggies from 20 to thirty miles away. There would be well over a hundred people at it.

James Hay Dickie was a farmer at Carlyle 20 miles east; he took it upon himself to advertise the picnic in that district and went with his family.

Going over a boggy spot on Section 39 his wagon sank and the horses were unable to carry on. After some difficulty he managed to get help and came on up to the picnic. He acted as master of ceremonies throughout the day.

Jack Hislop and Jack Anderson went up and made a picnic ground by cutting trees and clearing a place in the shade to sit and built a long table with stumps and planks which they brought from home. They made seats by nailing planks to tree roots, when people arrived they took the food baskets and put them in the shade to keep cool.

Jack Hislop's sister, Annie (Mrs Dugald Strother) was appointed sports convener.

There was a baseball game between the Clare boys and the Carlyle boys. The Carlyle team won.

At dinner time everyone sat down to a well-set table. Long linen clothes were spread over the planks and the food was cut and put on plates and passed. Everyone brought dishes for their own family there were enough to go around.

These picnics became a yearly tradition and for years, long after the railway came in, the 1st of July was picnic day at Picnic Hill.

1. To what religious services did you go when you first settled in your district?

We went to the Methodist Church.

Where did your neighbors go to church?

There was one church only, settlers went to the Methodist church or stayed at home.

How long was it after the first settlers came to your area before services of church worship were organized?

"Shortly" we had prayer and praise services. The first meeting to organize the church proper was held on July 28, 1885.

2. By whom were religious services held in your community before a regular church became established (by a clergyman from some other place, etc.)? Give details of the arrangement, telling where services were held, and give dates, if possible.

The Primitive Methodist Colonization Co. were given the grant of land to settle with colonists. Many of the settlers who came had been local preachers in England. Services were held in homes tents and in the open.

How was the clergyman supported?

After organization, the church was for many years partially supported by the Missionary fund.

3. Was the school house used for church services? Give dates.

The school house called "The Hall" was built in 1885-6, and was used for all purposes, Church, public meetings, School after 1885.

Was it used by congregations of more than one denomination on alternate Sundays?

There was only the Methodist Church. The settlers went to that church if they went at all.

Did the same congregation ever support both types of services and give equal financial support?

Everyone that lived at Pheasant Forks, if they gave to any Church gave to the Methodist Church.

Where did the clergyman (or clergymen) live, and how far was it from the school house?

We had an un-ordained student Minister from the year 1886. He "bashed" in a small log building that had been built for the first store, (own room)

How did he get to the school house to conduct services?

He walked.

The Hall was built at the little center, near the P.O. It was no distance.

Was he entertained in homes or supplied with accommodation for the night?

He went to one of the houses to conduct service, he would be given accommodation for the night. But he had a little "jumper" and pony.

Were services continued throughout the winter months, as well as other seasons of the year?

Yes, services were continued throughout the winter months.

Who put on the fire for school house services in winter?

There was a little center, as I have explained, near the P.O. One of the young men near by would put on the fire.

What other places of appointments, did the clergyman have besides the one at your school house?

There were three other appointments where services were held in homes.

The Minister could not get to all each Sunday, so one of the Local Preachers would be assigned to take the services alternately. There was a "Plan."

Describe the financial arrangements.

There was a collection at each service, but there was little money in those early days, so the Church was supported by the Missionary Society, Head quarters in Toronto.

41. What do you think are the most important changes in your community since you first came West?

When we went to the Pheasant Forks district in 1883, it was virgin prairie. The first very few settlers went in 1882, when the Colonization Co. was formed and the grant of land given to the Company by the Government. So there were a few little log and sod shanties or huts; one could hardly call them houses. The picture enclosed of a typical house was built by Mr. Lovendige in 1884, and afterwards shingled. The Primitive Methodist Colony

W.A. Cooke D.D.

These are notes concerning the Primitive Methodist Colony, written as requested by the Rev. A.W. Kenner, D.D., for the Archives of the United Church of Canada. They may also be of interest to those whose parents were among the early settlers.

The Colonization Company issued a promotion pamphlet in 1882 or early in 1883, and I quote verbatim the list of Officers and the first paragraph.

"The Primitive Methodist Colony, North West Territories".

President - R. Irving Walker, Esq., J.P.
Vice-President - Rev. J.C. Ancliff M.A.
Treasurer - Rev. J. Walker
Secretary - Rev. Wm. Bee
Colony Agent - C.S. Willis
Office - 31 Adelaide St., Toronto, Can.

This Colonization Company was formed in the beginning of 1882, for the purpose of affording Primitive Methodists and their families and their friends of whatever religious denomination the opportunity of locating together so as to more easily secure religious, educational, and social advantages in the North West, which was then and is still attracting so many people from England and older provinces of the Dominion and the United States.

In February 1882 a grant of land was made to the Company, the land granted by the Dominion Government, being the first grant made to any company and the land granted was the first choice from among the Colonization lands of the attractive Qu'Appelle District. The company, without loss of time went to work to secure settlers. They took the lead in settlement and have been rewarded by a large number of contented hopeful colonists on their lands who speak in glowing terms of the location and their own prospects.

For many years the nearest railway station was Wolseley on the main line of the C.P.R., which was completed, from the East as far as Broadview in 1883. Settlers drove north across the Qu'Appelle Valley and river and after travelling about twenty-five or thirty miles came to the South edge of the colony, which extended some seventeen miles further north and was about twelve to eighteen miles from east to west. On the south side were the Pheasant Hills with bluffs and sloughs, part of the colony. Many of the settlers had ox teams and the trip from Wolseley to the Colony took two or three days.

Rev. Wm. Bee in promoting the settlement went to England and interviewed prospective settlers, some of whom paid their entrance fees for specific half sections, which they accepted on his report and recommendation. Perhaps about seventy-five percent of the early settlers and were Methodists. Others were of English stock who had lived in Ontario before coming to the Colony. Some few were Anglicans, and a number who called themselves Christians and Believers, but were known as Plymouth Brethren held service every Sunday in the log house of one of the settlers. Methodist services were held in the Hall at Pheasant Forks and in the homes of the Rev. C.S. Willis, north of the Forks, in the home of Mr. T. Pallister at the extreme west of the colony.

A year or so later, in the east part of the colony service was held in the home of Mr. Thos. Loveridge.

To maintain these services, the old Methodist circuit plan of local preachers was followed. Some had been "on the plan" as accredited preachers in the circuits from which they came. Among them were men well read in general literature and Divinity, able preachers; men of fine sterling character, altogether an outstanding group of laymen. The list included John Allen, Richard Amy, John Barnsley, Thos. Loveridge, Henry Morley, Thos. Todd.
Wm. Watts, and perhaps others. Samuel Barnsley and Jas. Glover were young men. The plan was to put younger men, beginning their work with older men in conducting a service. W. A. Cooke (the writer) was another young man associated with one of the older men.

The Manitoba Conference of the Methodist Church, early included the Colony in its list of stations, and in the Minutes of 1885 the appointment read:

"Regina District, Fort Qu'Appelle, and P.M. Colony.—Oliver Darwin under superintendent of Qu'Appelle: C. S. Willis Superannuated, The Superintendent of Qu'Appelle was Superintendent of District". Thos Lawson.

The Company's Pamphlet named J. M. Peregrin of Hamilton, as the first settler on the Colony. He opened a store at Pheasant Forks, in which the Post Office was situated, and commenced a stage from Wolseley for mail and passengers. Others in the number of "contented, hopeful Colonists" named in the circular are H. G. Stillborn, and three brothers, John Allen, W. J. Hartwell, J. P. Webster, Telfer Brown, James Franks (1883) who succeeded Mr. Peregrin in 1887 as Postmaster and store-keeper. The local preachers named earlier, Geo. Glover, John Cooke (father of writer) and family were from Gainsby Lincolnshire. Other names that come to mind are Alf. and Bob Kent, Wm. Kirk, Garner, Wheelon, Ward, Benner, Teece and North, who was a carpenter and dove-tailed the corners of most of the log houses the settlers built, out of logs from the Pheasant Hills.

There are still (1952) descendents of the original settlers farming on the Colony. The Stillborns, Barnsleys, Aldous, Kirks, Wards, and others. Some became tired of waiting for the promised railway and moved away to other parts nearer to the railway.

I, personally, lived on the Colony for a few months only in the summer of 1883, and the spring of 1884, (although I visited my parents there often after that) I am indebted to Mr. Albert Lovendridge, Grenfell, Sask., for reminding me of people and events mentioned in these notes. He also let me see the Company's Pamphlet from which I have quoted.

Rev. W. A. Cooke D.D.
1742 Western Parkway
Vancouver, B.C.

Pioneer Churches.

1. To what religious services did you go when you first settled in your district? My first religious service was the Sunday school started by my father, John Brown, and Mrs. C. P. Murray. Where did your neighbors go to church? Services were held in private homes, led by laymen or a missionary from another field. How long was it after the first settlers came to your area before services of church worship were organized? Possibly a year.

2. By whom were religious services held in your community before a regular church became established (by a clergyman from some other place, etc.)? Give details of the arrangement, telling where services were held, and give dates if possible. A student from La'Appelle or Fort La'Appelle would come and hold service in private home about once a month. How was the clergyman supported? By the collection and donations received.

3. Was the school house used for church services? Give dates. Was it used by congregations of more than one denomination on alternate Sundays? Did the same congregation ever support both types of services and give equal financial support? Where did the clergyman (or clergymen) live, and how far was it from the school house? How did he get to the school house to conduct services? Was he entertained in homes or supplied with accommodation for the night? Often stayed at our home or with other friends. Were services continued throughout the winter months, as well as other seasons of the year? No, he usually rode horseback and it was too cold for the trip. Who put on the fire for school house services in winter? What other charges, or appointments, did the clergyman have besides the one at your school house? Describe the financial arrangements.

4. Were homes or other buildings such as stores used for church services in your community? Yes. Describe the arrangements. Standing there or no.
5. If you had a church building, give the date it was built. **1890**
   Who designed the building? **A.J. Clement**
   Who built it? **Volunteers**
   What material was it made of? **Brick**
   How many people did it seat? **75 to 100**
   What was the name and denomination of the church?
   **Indian Head Presbyterian Church (St. Andrews)**

6. Describe the steps taken in arranging for the building of the church, telling who started it, how money was secured, etc.
   The Mission Board promised a percentage if the residents paid up the rent. There was a debt on the church for a number of years.

How many families were in the congregation? **Would say about twenty-five**

7. Describe any make-shifts or savings resorted to in the building of the church, and in securing furniture and supplies for it.
   Homemade benches with backs, cushions supplied by the ones who wanted a soft seat. Little table and kitchen chair for minister. No organ. Hymn books were donated and also used for Sunday School.

8. Is this first building still in use? **No**
   If not, tell why it is not used now, and what happened to it.
   **Torn down and some other building put in its place**

9. When did you have a resident clergyman? **1891**
   Where did he come from? **Fort St. Appelle**
   What provision was made for living quarters for him—a residence built, etc.? **He built a residence for himself of brick and it is still in use.**

10. Did any other denomination use this church building for services? **Do not think so**
    Describe the arrangement.

11. Tell what other churches were built in your community, either before your church was built, or any time since. Give dates if possible, denomination of church, and any changes which have occurred in the use of the building—that is, if some denomination other than the one who built it is now using the church, or if it is used for some other purpose.
    Our church was first built. The Anglicans built a church which was later torn down and a new one built more in the heart of the district. A Methodist church was later built but at time of Union was sold to Oddfellows but was badly gutted by fire two years ago.
    Are all these churches in town? **Yes** If not, give distances from town, and from one another.
    The first Anglican church was about two miles from heart of town.
    If not built in town, why were they not built there? Lord Brassey had a large farm and he donated the land for church and Bishop's Court. The court later was turned into an old man's home. Do not know if it is standing there or no.

Most of the families would attend a church if their own was not available.

Can not say.

It was seldom we were without; after securing a resident clergyman but a layman would carry on in his absence.

Who was in charge of these and helped with the teaching? A man for dept. Mothers or someone interested to teach the classes.

20. What organization (or organizations) was formed to help with the support of the church? Ladies Aid. Woman's Missionary Society

How many women or men belonged to it?

It was a drive of about 13 miles and parents and children would go in buggies, buckboards or democrats according to size of family. Sandwiches, cupcakes, pies and cakes with homemade for children and tea for older people. Foot races, ball games, playing on beach etc.

There was lots of good plain food then with no fillings while now the food is more for show. The way it is decorated.

In the old days fifty cents was a good price for a good dinner. Today it is a dollar or more a plate.

Prayer meeting usually Wednesday evening. Young Peoples' Meeting one night a week.

2. By whom were religious services held in your community before a regular church became established (by a clergyman from some other place, etc.)? Give details of the arrangement, telling where services were held, and give dates if possible. The neighbors held a local Sabbath school, taking turns about at the different homes.

How was the clergyman supported? The first minister was Rev. John Ferry, he had a farm in the 2nd Appelle Valley. The people contributed what they could and I believe received some help from England.

3. Was the school house used for church services? Give dates. The schoolhouse was used from about 1889 until 1897 when the Methodist Church was built.

Was it used by congregations of more than one denomination on alternate Sundays? Yes, Methodists and Presbyterians used it almost every Sunday morning and evening.

Did the same congregation ever support both types of services and give equal financial support? Yes, they attended each other's services and contributed what they could.

Where did the clergyman (or clergymen) live, and how far was it from the school house? Mr. Ferry lived in the valley near his farm. The Methodist minister, in the first year, was a student. Supplies, Sunday, and meals, boarded and dormed.

How did he get to the school house to conduct services? By horse and buggy.

Was he entertained in homes or supplied with accommodation for the night? Yes, he was entertained in the homes.

Were services continued throughout the winter months, as well as other seasons of the year? Yes, unless weather conditions made it impossible for the minister to come.

Who put on the fire for school house services in winter? I think probably who ever lived nearest. Later, a stove took over.

What other charges, or appointments, did the clergyman have besides the one at your school house? Late, the Presbyterian minister had Abernethy and sometimes Hill Hill.

Describe the financial arrangements. A collection was taken every service, a canvass went annually and secured much book money. The balance was used for the school fund.

On a neighboring district, Chichny, service was held in the homes for some years until their school house was built. They also held services out doors—Camp meeting in summer. This worked best all day.

What was the name and denomination of the church? Kenly Methodist Church.

6. The work done now is much more elaborate and of course higher priced

There was the Christian Endeavor, a weekly meeting members taking the trip by turn. There were good meetings

I think I have told you about this. I believe this communion roll would be in possession of the United Church at Abernethy. Mr. Reid would probably be able to tell you.
One incident I am going to relate, whether not asked for. This is to do with the Indian Rebellion of 1835.

Near the Qu'Appelle Valley, on the plains where off I have written, there were a few pioneer settlers about seven or eight families. Rumors came from time to time about the uprising of the Indians. One day an elderly Miles man—John Fischer—went from house to house telling the settlers that the Indians were coming to raid the plains, warning them to hide their cattle, destroy the house, and kill as many of the settlers as they could. "Oh," said Mr. Fischer, "you will all come down to my valley."

The men decided that a meeting should be held. They gathered together at the home of Mr. Tim Perkins on Sunday morning. The meeting was opened with prayer by Mrs. Anderson, who later organized the Sabbath School.

Plans were discussed. Some spoke of building a fort, others didn't want to build anything. They came up with all their farm implements and whatever they could get. The idea was abandoned. There were small babies and it was very exciting. Without being attacked, finally Mr. Perkins stood up tall, speaking for bidding. A real pioneer man! "Well neighbors, put your selves in my place. I have a good wife, children, and a good fight. My children come with me."

This seemed to decide the little meeting. They closed with the old hymn "What a Friend We Have in Jesus." Oh, we weak and heavy laden, combined with a load of our precious sorrow still goes rising. Take it to the Lord in Prayer."

They returned to their homes. This settlement was never attacked. They did come across some Indians but they were always friendly.

The first meeting of women she had interested in the new venture was called by Mrs. Bert Talmay to meet at her house on February 7 for the purpose of organizing a country-woman's society for mutual help and encouragement. Prosperity Pointers, Feb. 14—“Our chief item of news for this issue is the formation of the Prosperity Homemakers' Society, which has been organized to meet the need of our women-folk for enlarged social opportunities. 33. Is the church as important a place now of people gathering together for companionship and sociality as it was in the early years? No, I do not think so. Explain. In the early days when there was no radio - telephone - T-V or other forms of entertainment - movies, etc., people had to rely on the Church to sponsor their entertainment and social life and of course the main socials were in the form of community picnics when everyone attended to talk and associate with their neighbors.

34. Is the first membership roll of your church still in the community? I don't know. If you can, give the name of the person who has it.

Do you have any pictures or photographs of your earliest church or of homes where the first services were held, or do you know of anyone who has such pictures? No - no one took photos of anything in the very early days.

35. Describe any special features or unusual incidents of pioneer churches, or anything connected with it which you found interesting, not already mentioned. (Use other sheets, or back of this sheet if necessary.) It seems to me that the people of the Churches in the early days were much more friendly than they are today; however, this was probably due to the very necessity of depending so much on each other. Circumstances in the early days, when people existed sometimes on practically nothing made it absolutely that all depended on one another in time of need and you could always rely on people helping as much as possibly - thus resulting in a fast common-bond friendship which does not to my mind exist today in the same degree.

(see other side of this sheet for further information)
The following are a few other items of interest which I might mention in so far as our religion was concerned in the early days.

As I mentioned before in this Questionnaire, our particular settlement was made up of Baptists, and religion seemed to be taken much more sincerely then than they do now, and I might also state that for the most part people practiced what they preached in the community. There was a good fellowship in the Church.

Once a year there would be a Baptism Service. This would be held out in the open air near a slough or lake, etc. The people who were to be baptized would be put into a wagon to which a team of horses was hitched, and were driven to the edge of the body of water concerned. The Minister would walk into the water waist deep, and the laymen would lead the people into the water and duck them right under; then other assisting laymen would take them back to the nearest farm house to change their clothes. The women would wear pure white dresses and the men would wear an old suit.

In connection with the Sunday School Christmas Tree each year we did not have a Santa Claus. The parents used to put gifts for the children on the tree and the Minister would present the gifts to the children, calling the names. The gift in most years was a bag of candy and that was something worth having in the early days. The tree was usually decorated by the women of the Church.

Pioneer Churches.

1. To what religious services did you go when you first settled in your district?
   When we arrived in Saskatchewan in 1889, services were held in the Billington school alternately by Presbyterian and Methodist.

   Where did your neighbors go to church?
   All the settlers that went to services went to Billington school attending both services.

   How long was it after the first settlers came to your area before services of church worship were organized?

2. By whom were religious services held in your community before a regular church became established (by a clergyman from some other place, etc.)? Give details of the arrangement, telling where services were held, and give dates if possible.
   The services were supplied by regular ministers from Grenfell and Broadview.

   How was the clergyman supported?
   The services in the Billington school were supported by the missionary societies of the Presbyterian and Methodist churches.

3. Was the school house used for church services? Give dates.
   The Billington school was used for religious services from 1889 to 1893.

   Was it used by congregations of more than one denomination on alternate Sundays? By Presbyterian and Methodist alternately.

   Did the same congregation ever support both types of services and give equal financial support?
   They gave alike to both denominations.

   Where did the clergyman (or clergymen) live, and how far was it from the school house?
   In Grenfell or Broadview twelve miles to each.

   How did he get to the school house to conduct services?
   By horse and buggy or was driven by someone.

   Was he entertained in homes or supplied with accommodation for the night?
   Quite often the Methodist minister was entertained at our home for the night or for dinner on Sunday.

   Were services continued throughout the winter months, as well as other seasons of the year?
   Yes, driving out from town with horses and cutter.

   Who put on the fire for school house services in winter? The first person to reach the school.

   What other charges, or appointments, did the clergyman have besides the one at your school house?
   Service in which ever town he resided, also in other schools both out from the town of Grenfell & Broadview.

   Describe the financial arrangements.
   The people paid what could of the missionary society make up the balance.

4. Were homes or other buildings such as stores used for church services in your community? Describe the arrangements.
   The Billington school was used until the Edgewood school was built; the services were then taken to Edgewood school and the Presbyterians with Drew's services were supplied by the Methodist from Broadview.
5. If you had a church building, give the date it was built. **1903**
   Who designed the building? Mr. Thomas Brownridge & Mr. Eli Vessey
   Who built it? Swedish builders from Whitewood.
   What material was it made of? Lumber. How many people did it seat? Seventy.
   What was the name and denomination of the church? Bethel Methodist.

6. Describe the steps taken in arranging for the building of the church, telling who started it, how money was secured, etc.
   A building committee was formed consisting of three men of ladies and the district. Donald McGregor, Thos Brownridge & Eli Vessey—a was formed.
   How many families were in the congregation? Five regulars & several others at times.

7. Describe any make-shifts or savings resorted to in the building of the church, and in securing furniture and supplies for it.
   I'm raising funds the ladies aid would give each person who by rising would take it. Ten cents at a social held at Easter. This sum to be returned at a social held at thanksgiving, with what they had made savings.

8. Is this first building still in use? No.
   If not, tell why it is not used now, and what happened to it. It was closed for a time after union and finally fell out of use as the families that supported it moved away. It was sold to a man outside in Greenfield & torn down some years ago.

9. When did you have a resident clergyman? Never. Where did he come from?

10. Did any other denomination use this church building for services?
    Describe the arrangement. The United Church had services in it for a time.

11. Tell what other churches were built in your community, either before your church was built, or any time since. Give dates if possible, denomination of church, and any changes which have occurred in the use of the building—that is, if some denomination other than the one who built it is now using the church, or if it is used for some other purpose.
    The Presbyterians built a stone church in the Spring Lake district next to the Edgewood district—called it Popular Grove. It was supplied from Broadview and is still in use.

Are all these churches in town? No. If not, give distances from town, and from one another. Bethel was 1/2 mile from Greenfield & the same from Broadview & 6 miles from Popular Grove.

If not built in town, why were they not built there? There was all the churches in these towns that the towns needed.
12. Was your church established as a home mission? Yes, while on the Board.

Describe the arrangements as to finance, student ministers, etc.

Student ministers frequently served on the Broadview Church field which was under the home missionary society of the Brethren.

13. If families did not have a church of their own denomination in the community, did they usually go to some other church, or not attend at all?

Some came to Bethel; others did not go to church at all.

Did they have any special religious service of some kind in the home if they could not go to church, or if there was no public religious service?

Not that I know of.

If families had been attending and supporting a church other than their own denomination, or had not attended because their own church was not present, how well did they support their own church if it became established in their community at a later date?

14. How often and at what time were services held in the church, school or other building?

Every other Sunday in the school before the church was built and the store in the church.

15. Did laymen conduct church services when a clergymen was not available?

Describe the circumstances.

Services were supplied both in the school and church by local preachers from Owenfield district.

16. Did you have an organ for the service? Yes

Who played it? Several different persons, Joe Brownridge, Mrs. Beaton, Henry Adams.

When was it bought? 1905

How was the money raised for it? By socials.

17. Did you have a choir? Yes

How many were in it? Twelve at best.

Who started it? Mrs. Reeve

When? 1903

Were any of the persons who led the choir or sang in it trained musicians? No

Explain. Just the young people of the district clubbed together to help with the singing.

18. Was any other kind of music or musical instrument used in the services?

Describe. No.

19. What kind of religious instruction for the young, such as Sunday School or Catechism classes, were held? Give dates when they were started.

There was a Young People's Epworth League of Christians.

How often were they held? Every Sunday in connection with the Church, supported at half cost by the minister.

How many children attended? Church, supported at half cost by the minister.

Who was in charge of these and helped with the teaching? Minister.

20. What organization (or organizations) was formed to help with the support of the church?

A Ladies Aid

What year was it started? 1902

How often did it meet? Just when business required attention.

How many women or men belonged to it? Seven women, Mrs. McGregor, Mrs. Lamb, Mrs. Brownridge, Mrs. Beaton, Mrs. Reeve, Mrs. Beragston, Mrs. Bell.
21. In what year was the first church picnic held? 1904 Where? On the church grounds.

Describe the church picnics of early days, telling how many attended, what you had to eat and drink, what amusements there were, changes which occurred in later years, and any other details about them which you remember. (There are questions on the Pioneer Recreation Questionnaire dealing with picnics, so if you wish to give the information there, you need not repeat it here.)

Tables were kept outside the church, a good supper was served cold meals, potato salad, lettuce salad, cake & pies in plain dance of ice cream, lemonade, played ballet had a social time.

22. In what year was the first fowl supper or bazaar held? None where?

Was it held every year after that?

What differences do you notice between the dishes served at the suppers in the early days, and those served now?

What differences are there in serving methods (help yourself, plates served already filled, etc.)? Everything was put on the table if you served yourself.

What changes are there in the price of suppers? There was never any charge at Bethel suppers, picnics or concerts. A free will offering.

Describe any changes which you have noticed in the needlework offered for sale, in type of work or articles brought, those that were most popular at various times, changes in price, or any other details which you may remember.

The chief entertainment of the year was the church anniversary held the last Sunday in August with two services on Sunday and dinner on Monday with usually from 75 to 100 guests. Was a concert of some kind held in connection with the suppers or bazars in the first years? Describe.

Concert in the church at night. There was no charge for the dinner but a plate was on the table for free will offerings.

23. Describe any other activities that were carried on to assist in raising money for the church.

There was social & concert twice a year in the spring and in the fall only free will offerings were received.

24. Name any other organizations or meetings associated with the church, telling when they were started, how often they met, and their purpose and activities.

The Epworth League had social evenings quite often and one winter there was a skatesphere club formed & met from house to house.

25. When was any plan of systematic giving for the support of the church and clergyman adopted?

Of what nature, - weekly envelopes, etc.?
26. What interest or activity was there in the support of home missions? There was a collection taken once a year for home missions and foreign missions. A missionary service held once a year for foreign missions.

27. How far did some of the people have to travel to church service? Five miles.

What means of travel was used? In 1899 there were open lumber wagons later horses to buckboards.

28. What nationalities were represented in the congregation, and in approximately what proportion? In the early days it was English & Dutch settlers of people from Ontario. Later European people came to the district but they did not come to the church.

29. Were there special revival or mission services in the early days? Occasionally there were special services, held by a minister from Broadview, Mr. Demuth & Mrs. Lewis from Grenfell & Others.

30. What arrangements were there to provide for the training of the clergy? None.

31. What differences did you notice in church life on the prairies as compared with the community you came from? There was much more fellowship between the different denominations, this was largely because there was only one church in the district.

32. To what extent did the social life of the community centre around the church service (held in the church, school or other building) in the early days? There was little or no social life outside the church. Later when the church was closed there was card dancing in the school, now there is no social life whatever in the district.

Is the church as important a place now of people gathering together for companionship and sociability as it was in the early years? Explain. Now in 1953 there is no church & no social life in the district. Buses are used to take the people to town when the snow is bad in winter, there are no social activities.

34. Is the first membership roll of your church still in the community? It was always in town either Grenfell or Broadview.

If you can, give the name of the person who has it. It is still in these hands I believe.

Do you have any pictures or photographs of your earliest church or of homes where the first services were held, or do you know of anyone who has such pictures?

35. Describe any special features or unusual incidents of pioneer churches, or anything connected with it which you found interesting, not already mentioned. (Use other sheets, or back of this sheet if necessary.)

In the year 1908 when the church anniversary of Grenfell was held, there followed an epidemic of typhoid fever, there was 62 cases of fever that could be traced to this supper. There was never another dinner & supper held at Bethel Church.

Settlement of the Forest district was commenced in the summer of 1882. In the spring of '83 the homesteads were entered for and cultivation of the land commenced. It is worthy of note that these pioneers like the Pilgrim Fathers of America, brought with them and established their faith and their church.

They met in the homes of Alex and Robert Martin and without the aid of a minister, held weekly services. Hymn books were sent them from Ontario by Mrs. Agnes Balfour (known to most of you as Grandma Balfour). The spring of 1884 Mrs. Balfour and Mrs. John Martin with their young children came to the settlement also Mrs. Donald Wilkie and Mrs. Sidney Armstrong. The only service led by a minister of which we have any record up to June 1884, was held by Rev. Wm. Martin of Norwich Ont. In June 1884 the district was visited by Rev. Alex Urquhart of Regina and arrangements were made for the formation of a congregation. On July 11th, Rev Dr. Robertson and Rev Alex Urquhart visited the field and a congregation comprised of the following members was formed: John Bruce, Wm. Jamieson, Arthur Jamieson, Alex Martin and wife, Robert Martin and wife, David Martin, Mrs. Balfour, Charles Sherriff, Donald Wilkie and wife John Martin and wife. Services were held once a month by Rev. Alex Urquhart of Regina in a small shack belonging to Wm. Jamieson. It was situated where Alex McEwen now lives. The shack was without windows or doors. The heat came of boards placed on blocks of wood; the building which consisted of a packing box was conspicuously low in comparison to Mr. Urquhart's splendidly tall figure. This defect was later remedied by adding a sloping stand to the top of the box.

It was here the first baby was baptized, Grandma Balfour supplying the bowl of water and towel and Mrs. John Martin the baby. The baby was named Jean Isobel and by the minister's request the name Urquhart was added. She is now Mrs. M.C. Ross of Regina.

In 1886, the year following the rebellion a small frame church was built on Section 10, north of Charles Sherriffs buildings. It was later moved to the location of our present church. It was later sold and the building is now part of Mr. R. Ralls house. It was built by volunteer labor, the lumber being hauled from Regina. Students were sent out by the Knox College Missionary Society of Toronto and for a few years there were no winter services. Rev. Peter Struthers collected students and to their splendid qualities all the pioneers testify. In April 1885 Mr. Manson was sent. He also occupied the field in '87, the year the first church was built. It was opened July 11th, for regular service, Rev. Alex Urquhart dispensed the sacrament and several new members were received. In 1887 James Drummond was the student and that year Sunday School and Bible Classes were started. He was followed by John Conning in 1888, F.F. McPherson in 1889, Mr. McPherson took up a homestead and was the second teacher in Forest School in 1891. Wm. Gauld was sent as Student in charge in 1890. Later Mr. Gauld went to Formosa after his ordination and served as missionary there for thirty years until his death several years ago. Mr. Barron held winter services in the winter of 1890-'91 and Mr. Scott came for the summer months. A session was formed at the beginning of 1891 and T.C. Tate and John Martin were elected and ordained elders by Rev. Carmichael. The winter services were supplied by Mr. Brandon. In 1892 G.A. Wilson was the missionary for the summer and Mr. Watt for the winter. A request was sent in for an ordained missionary until such a time as the congregation could call a minister. J.B. McKechnie was appointed and ordained for the work commencing his duties in May 1893 and continuing his work in '94. In 1895 Wm. McLeod was the missionary in charge followed by Rev. T. Hunter Boyd in 1896. Services were also being held at Cottonwood, Longlaketon and Stoney Beach. Carssdale was the name by which our congregation was known because...

The mail was distributed from Mr. Edward Carss's and the post office was named Carasdale.

The students all used the same means of transportation covering the ground on the back of a bay pony called "Billy". He had been a scout pony during the rebellion and had evidently absorbed the spirit of the times, for he was on certain occasions very hard to move; in fact he was balky. Mr. Drummond and Mr. R.E. Knowles spent one day trying to drive him. Their day was one of experiences but not of success and they decided that "Billy" should be re-named "Sooner" as they said he would sooner stand than go. Mr. Brandon also carried with him from the field, memories of a cold dip in the Wascana River when "Billy" decided it was the proper place in which to lie down. Billy was afterwards sold to Mr. John Martin for five dollars where some years later he ended his term of service to humanity by lying down in the deep waters of the Wascana and refusing all attempts at rescue.

The expense of the missionaries was paid by the congregation and at times it was not an easy task. Every family could tell, if it would, of sacrifices made that the work might go forward. As Mrs. Balfour wrote in a letter to relatives in the East: "We always have enough to pay for what we eat and support our missionary. One family you know well wore homemade boots of cloth and skins one winter so that the ten dollars saved could help keep the church open. We with our comfortable homes with their modern equipment and luxuries where do we stand in this matter? Can we proudly stand by these dear pioneers and say 'I too have given till it hurts' that the work of God may go on? Who would say their sacrifices were of no avail."

I would we could stand in the door of this little frame church on the prairie and watch the people gather for the service. Some on foot, some on oxen, some with horses, with stoneboats, wagons and buckboards. One family's appearance consisted of the wheels of a wagon with a plank from front to rear bolstered and another plank lower down for the feet to rest on. Another family came on a stoneboat as far as a nearby slough where they tethered the oxen rather than risk unfavorable comparison with more aristocratic vehicles. But they came and came regularly, and they prospered and of course their church prospered too. In 1897 thirty years ago they decided to erect a bigger and better building so they built our present church and they opened it free of debt. Volunteer labor was used as far as possible. I understand that the late Mr. George Kinnon drew the first load of gravel and I know it was a generous one like the heart of the man. The name of the church was changed from "Carasdale" to "Forest", a reminder of the town in Ontario Mt. Forest from which most of the founders of the church had come. At the opening of the church the singing was led by Mr. John Martin without the aid of any instrument until 1900 when an organ was installed.

The names on the communion roll in 1897 are as follows: John Martin, Mrs. John Martin, Donald Wilkie, Mrs. Donald Wilkie, Alexander Mutch, Mrs. Alexander Mutch, George Mutch, Robert Kinnon, Mrs. Robert Kinnon, Miss Jessie Kinnon, George Kinnon, Mrs. George Kinnon, John Campbell, Albert Webb, Mrs. Albert Webb, Duncan Wilkie, Flora Wilkie, David McArthur, Mrs. David McArthur, Frederick Tate, John Balfour, Mrs. John Balfour, Mrs. Cairns, Bella Cairns, Archibald Cairns, Charles Sherriffs, James Mutch, Mrs. James Mutch.

"Hedwigsford held its Harvest Festival on Tues Oct 11th 1892. The day throughout was miserably wet but notwithstanding the weather a fairly good number sat down to tea at 6pm in the School and afterwards attended the Thanksgiving Service. Rev. J. W. Harrison of Marbleton T. D. died
Nov 4th 1952 in 96th year.

I knew this man personally in 1889 when we
arrived in Apr. 1889 at Regina from England, a party
of 9, I am now the sole survivor of that party.
We settled at Hednecford (now Edenwood) NE of
Regina & Mr. Harrison started the church work
in that settlement which was at that time all
English, later in early 1900s Germans came in.

Copy of Obit:

Born in city of Glasgow Scotland on Dec 5, 1856
Educated in Cornwall. Came to Regina in 1889
to take land & farmed for a few years at
Hednecford. He was given a Lay Reader's
license & helped to organize church work in
that part of the diocese of La Ronge (holding
services in his own house & also neighbours).
He was ordained in 1904 being Sacrament
of Ottawa Mission Sect. Then was principal
of Gordon School 1905-1907. Health failed &
his doctor ordered lower elevation so he joined
the Diocese of Quebec where he lived to the end.

I left the settlement to live at Broadview in 1897
so have no data on formation of permanent school
or church.

J. C. Wilson.

Moosomin Nov 5/34

Moosomin Methodist (now United) church was built in 1889. You will agree that it was a bold move for a small congregation in a small village to make in the early days of the west.

This church has had two major changes since first built apart from removing the front entrance and putting in modern heating and lighting. The basement is full pipe, the walls of which are stone. The superstructure is of solid brick. By the way these bricks were made within 10 miles of Moosomin in a brick yard on the banks of the Superwinn Creek.

The strange fact is here. The corner stone of this Methodist Church was laid by a clergyman of the Anglican Church.

Led by the Most Worshipful Master, the Grand Master, the Rev. Canon O'Meara, proceeded to the site of the building where the Grand Master placed the corner stone in place; in the North East corner, and declared it well and truly laid. It costs us around today as the day it was said.

The corner stone is hidden in the picture by a bulletin board. The church has been in constant use ever since built.
